title: Markov Chain Monte Carlo Methods
description: Understanding MCMC methods for sampling from complex posterior distributions in Active Inference.
learning_objectives: Design Markov chains with desired stationary distributions
Apply MCMC in Active Inference contexts

content.overview: Markov Chain Monte Carlo methods generate samples from complex probability distributions by constructing Markov chains with the target distribution as their stationary distribution. They enable exact Bayesian inference when analytical methods are not available.

markov_chain_fundamentals.irreducibility: Can reach any state from any other state

common_mcmc_algorithms.implementation: Propose new state, accept with probability α

common_mcmc_algorithms.description: Sample each variable conditional on others
common_mcmc_algorithms.method: For each i, sample θ_i ~ p(θ_i | θ_{-i}, x)

common_mcmc_algorithms.description: Uses Hamiltonian dynamics for efficient exploration
common_mcmc_algorithms.dynamics: Molecular dynamics simulation in parameter space

convergence_diagnostics.geweke_test: Compare means from different parts of chain

examples.name: Beta-Binomial Posterior
examples.gibbs: Direct sampling if α, β are integers

practical_considerations.thinning: Take every k-th sample to reduce autocorrelation
practical_considerations.parallel_chains: Run multiple chains for better diagnostics

common_misconceptions.clarification: Samples are asymptotically exact, not exactly exact

common_misconceptions.misconception: All MCMC algorithms are equally efficient
common_misconceptions.clarification: Efficiency depends on target distribution and algorithm choice

common_misconceptions.misconception: MCMC is always better than variational methods
common_misconceptions.clarification: Each has advantages in different situations
